flowRoot.flowPara: (Basically anytime you are cutting something out of a piece then the vectors that will be cut must be part of
a single entity and you use Path-> Offset.
Alternatively, instead of Outset you can make the stroke style 0.00984252" and then choose Path->Stroke to Path.

Then Path -> Break Apart. Remove the fill and change the stroke color. Set the stroke size to be 0.002". Delete the interior paths associated with the original strokes. But I've never really done this.)

(tl;dr) In inkscape, the Path->Outset operation accounts for the kerf of the laser. If you have one part totally contained within the other (and not just bordering) then you need to subtract the contained part so that all vectors are within a single object. (You cannot simply combine them). See below for full explanation and pretty pictures.
The kerf of the laser is 0.5mm or 0.019685". One half of that is 0.25mm or 0.00984252".
There are two cases to consider.
1/ When an object is fully encolosed within another. We call the larger object the enclosure and the smaller object the small. Here is an example.
The rounded rectangle is the enclosure and the star is the small object.

If you were to cut along the lines of the object then you would result in a star which is too small by the kerf size of the layer. You lose 1/2 of kerf in the star shape when cutting the small and 1/2 of the kerf in the enclosure when cutting the star shape to the. It would look like this - note the white around the star when you zoom in. This is what is lost to the laser:

Instead you need to take the two shapes and subtract the interior one (the smaller) from the enclosure. Then you must outset the combined vectors to cut out the full enclosure. This will shrink the interior star which results in a smaller star but this smaller star is actually the same sized star after the laser kerf is taken into account. It also grows the exterior vectors to make the bounding part of the enclosure shape larger. Again, it won't actually be larger after the laser kerf is taken into account. Shown below is the black original and then the outset in green.
Black = Original (smaller subtracted from enclosure)
Green = Outset -- to be cut!

Now you still need to cut out the smaller shape. In this example it is the star. Take just the original star vector with no modifications to begin with. If you just cut out on those vector lines the kerf of the laser would make the star smaller than you want it. You must outset again. This time, since it is not a vector enclosed within a larger one, the outset will actually make the shape larger. But it won't actually be larger after the kerf of the laser is taken into account. Shown below is the black original and then the outset in green
Black = Just the smaller vector with no change
Green = Outset -- to be cut!

If you combine the result into a single view and show the enclosure as red and the smaller object as blue you get the following. Note that this time there is white inbetween the blue and red where the star is but the white actually shows the overlap between the two objects which will not exist after the laser vaporizes the kerf.
2/ When two objects are next to each other. Consider the Following.

Again - cutting on the line would result in a gap between the two pieces. The straight vertical lines could be smushed together resulting in an overall shape which was not as wide. But this won't work for the part in the middle with the diagonal lines. The horizontal space could be compressed there but the vertical part would not.

Here the solution is outset again. Just outset each and cut. The outset version grows the vectors which accounts for the kerf. No subtraction need occur here because the shapes of the pieces are distinct and not completely contained.
If you combine the resulting outset vectors into a single view and show the yellow left piece as red and the larger right-side piece as blue then you get:
Settings:
It does depend on the material and how much work the laser has to do in order to cut through it.
For some materials, such as 1/8" acrylic, the kerf of the laser is 0.25mm.

For a recent test, where I rastered Maple wood (1000x1000, S:15, P: 100, two times) and then inset a piece of 1.5mm walnet veneer, I had to use 0.12mm for the Path -> Outset setting. (To set the specific outset value for a single operation use Edit->Preferences->Behavior->Steps->Inset/Outset by.)
